items.title: provide an example for a decision with an attachment
items.body:
This is the first of a set of PRs related to attachments, we should provide examples for 
1. non annotated attachments of a decision (this PR)
2. inline annotated attachments of a decision
3. external annotated attachments of a decision

according to the application profile an attachment uses the property "eli:cites" and links to a resource of type "foaf:Document". I've included a citation of a related LegalExpression to make the difference more clear.

NOTE: GN currently doesn't at the LegalExpression type to it's citations.

items.title: Issue #158 - info.json V1.1
Europass export duplicates reports on multiple institutions
items.body:
The Europass XML creator duplicates reports that are covering multiple institutions. This leads to a validation error, as the report IDs must be unique. E.g.

```
<string>:0:0:ERROR:SCHEMASV:SCHEMAV_CVC_IDC: Element '{http://data.europa.eu/europass/qms-xml/schema/accreditation}accreditation': Duplicate key-sequence ['https://data.deqar.eu/report/48200'] in key identity-constraint '{http://data.europa.eu/europass/qms-xml/schema/accreditation}accreditationKey'.
```

It seems difficult to fully solve this now, as the Europass data model only allows accreditation entries referring to a single institution. But the short-term solution might be a simple addition of `distinct()` here:

https://github.com/EQAR/eqar_backend/blob/5b815615de4b4e1aa869a33cc3bdf9c220c37bce/connectapi/europass/accrediation_xml_creator.py#L65-L70

I guess the `Q(institutions__in=institutions)` filter duplicates rows for each matching institution.

(With the code L115-L118 it then will include only the first institution of each report however.)

items.title: definitions clarifications of conforms to

labels.name: due for closing
labels.description: Issue that has been addressed and it is going to be closed if there are no objection within 6 days

labels.name: feedback
labels.description: Issues stemming from external feedback to the WG

milestone.title: DCAT3 2PWD
milestone.description: This milestone reflects a prioritization of issues for the 2nd Public Working Draft of DCAT version 3.

items.body:
Hi,

`conforms to` appears twice as property. Having the definition _An established standard to which the described resource conforms._ 

However it is not clear to what the conforms to actually refers. To the metadata that is in the catalog, or the information that is described by the metadata.

the usage notes state
- [cataloged resource](https://w3c.github.io/dxwg/dcat/#Property:resource_conforms_to):  This property SHOULD be used to indicate the model, schema, ontology, view or profile that the cataloged resource content conforms to.
- [catalog record](https://w3c.github.io/dxwg/dcat/#Property:record_conforms_to): 
   This property SHOULD be used to indicate the model, schema, ontology, view or profile that the catalog record metadata conforms to. 
- [distribution](https://w3c.github.io/dxwg/dcat/#Property:record_conforms_to): This property SHOULD be used to indicate the model, schema, ontology, view or profile that this representation of a dataset conforms to. This is (generally) a complementary concern to the media-type or format. 

What does that mean for a Catalog, Dataset, DataService? Are that the rules imposed on the DCAT structure used? E.g. the rules from DCAT-AP (SE)?
Then I come to the distribution case which is not about the additional constraints on the metadata for the distribution, but about the actual content. E.g. I use the INSPIRE-address model. 
That is not the same interpretation for conforms-to. 

Suppose I have a harvesting data-portal like the European Data Portal, then it would be nice to know which metadata profile the descriptions conform to. Each entity conforms-to a EU memberstate profile. But know I cannot know that for distributions, because that describes the ontology used by the actual data.

items.title: Codes say they're in NUTS scheme but don't show up when building the tree top-down

labels.name: data
labels.description: Related to some underlying/upstream data issue

items.body: This causes some search results to return an empty codelist. E.g. search "Geography" for "wales" to see this: The reason the NUTS scheme appears but is empty is because the search returns some codes that are marked as being in that codelist, but don't appear when the tree is built from the top-down (which is how we currently fetch the data to build the tree UI). ---- In case it's helpful, these are the steps I did to get a hold of the relevant data and convince myself of what's going on (I did these from a repl with the namespaces from `ook.search.elastic.codes` loaded): - search for the code with id `http://data.europa.eu/nuts/code/UKL` ```clj (esd/search (esu/get-connection "http://localhost:9200") "code" "_doc" {:query {:match {:_id "http://data.europa.eu/nuts/code/UKL"}}}) ``` - Note `http://data.europa.eu/nuts/scheme/2016` is included in the schemes for that code (which is the "NUTS - Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics classification (2016)") one with the problem here) - Note it has no `topConceptOf`, so follow the broaders up: ```clj (esd/search (esu/get-connection "http://localhost:9200") "code" "_doc" {:query {:terms {:_id ["http://data.europa.eu/nuts/code/UK" "data/gss_data/trade/international-trade-in-services-by-subnational-areas-of-the-uk#concept-scheme/location/nuts"]}}}) ``` - Doing this again (following the `broader`s of those) never turns up the `http://data.europa.eu/nuts/scheme/2016` scheme

items.title: Versioning and resource status

milestone.title: DCAT3 FPWD
milestone.description: This milestone reflects a prioritization of issues for the First Public Working Draft of DCAT version 3.

items.body:
_Originally posted by @andrea-perego in https://github.com/w3c/dxwg/issues/93#issuecomment-469443517_
I don't remember if this was already mentioned, but another aspect of versioning may concern the resource "status" - e.g., draft, stable, deprecated, withdrawn.

The EU Publications Office maintains some reference code lists - the two that may be most relevant here are:
- [Dataset status](https://publications.europa.eu/en/web/eu-vocabularies/at-concept-scheme/-/resource/authority/dataset-status/?target=Browse)
- [Concept status](https://publications.europa.eu/en/web/eu-vocabularies/at-concept-scheme/-/resource/authority/concept-status/?target=Browse)

E.g., the dataset status code list above includes the following statuses (alphabetically ordered):

Code | Label | Definition
-- | -- | -- 
COMPLETED | completed | This dataset is considered to be complete, it holds all information that is intended.
DEPRECATED | deprecated | It is recommended that the contents of this dataset be no longer used.
DEVELOP | under development | This dataset is currently being assembled. It may be in an incomplete or faulty state.
DISCONT | discontinued | This dataset is no longer produced or updated.
WITHDRAWN | withdrawn | This dataset is no longer meant to be published.

The concept status code list includes additional statuses.

This information is clearly useful for administrative purposes, but relevant as well for users.

E.g., in the JRC Data Catalogue, these statuses determine where a dataset can be published (e.g., a dataset in draft status is not supposed to be published in production). On the other hand, deprecated, discontinued, or withdrawn records are not removed from the catalogue (because of the persistence policy we have in place), but they are "marked" as such, so that users are aware they shouldn't be used or are not longer available.

items.title: Max cardinality for dct:creator
items.body:
Currently, the max cardinality of `dct:creator` is set to 1 instead of N. 

This implies that a dataset or a catalogue can have at most 1 author/creator, which is not the case.

items.title: http://data.europa.eu/m8g/Participation bestaat niet.
items.body:
**Model(len) waarop de issue van toepassing is:** 
oslo:Dossier 
**Omschrijving van het probleem:** 
Er wordt binnen de Core Public Service Vocabulary (AP) (http://data.europa.eu/m8g/cpsvap rdf:type owl:Ontology) verwezen naar http://data.europa.eu/m8g/Participation als rdfs:isDefinedBy http://data.europa.eu/m8g/cpov, het Core Public Organisation Vocabulary. De klasse wordt dus niet gedefiniëerd binnen cpsvap.

Het statement dat deze klasse binnen http://data.europa.eu/m8g/cpov is gedefinieerd klopt niet.
maw. We gebruiken dingen waarvan we de aard niet kennen.

https://github.com/SEMICeu/CPOV/blob/master/releases/1.00/Core%20Public%20Organisation%20Vocabulary_v1.0.0.ttl
en
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/e-government-core-vocabularies/core-public-organisation-vocabulary


**Omschrijving van een mogelijke oplossing:**
Er bestaan binnen de provenance ontologie, waarop het grootste deel van oslo:Dossier is gebaseerd, meerdere qualificatie-klassen en -properties die een hele reeks van use-cases uitdrukkingen mogelijk maken.
Ik laat weten welke ik voor specifieke gevallen gebruik.

With [all geo codelists selected](http://localhost:3000/search?filters=%5B%22%5E+%22%2C%22Geography%22%2C%5B%22%5E+%22%2C%22data%2Fgss_data%2Ftrade%2Fdcms-sectors-economic-estimates-year-trade-in-services%23scheme%2Fcountry%22%2Cnull%2C%22data%2Fgss_data%2Ftrade%2Fhmrc-regional-trade-statistics%23scheme%2Fuk-region%22%2Cnull%2C%22data%2Fgss_data%2Ftrade%2Fons-exports-of-services-by-country-by-modes-of-supply%23scheme%2Fcountry%22%2Cnull%2C%22data%2Fgss_data%2Ftrade%2Fons-quarterly-country-and-regional-gdp%23scheme%2Freference-area%22%2Cnull%2C%22def%2Ftrade%2Fconcept-scheme%2Fcountry-area%22%2Cnull%2C%22def%2Ftrade%2Fconcept-scheme%2Fcountry-of-ownership%22%2Cnull%2C%22def%2Ftrade%2Fhmrc%2Fconcept-scheme%2Fcountry%22%2Cnull%2C%22http%3A%2F%2Fdata.europa.eu%2Fnuts%2Fscheme%2F2016%22%2Cnull%5D%5D), some rows (2 and 5) have no cell values in the geo column.

Not sure how this could be. Maybe their dimension points to a codelist but they don't use any of it's values...

items.title: Encoding problems with NUTS concept labels
items.body:
See [Thessaloniki](https://staging.gss-data.org.uk/resource?uri=http://data.europa.eu/nuts/code/EL522) for example.

There's some mistakes upstream.

The [source](https://data.europa.eu/euodp/repository/ec/estat/nuts/nuts.rdf) sometimes has two `skos:prefLabel`s for a resource - presumably these were intended to differ by language tag ([as permitted by the vocab](https://www.w3.org/2012/09/odrl/semantic/draft/doco/skos_prefLabel.html)) but no language tags are provided.

Presumably this is intended to provide a native name and a transliteration - e.g. code PL22 has "Śląskie" and "Slaskie". In most cases these labels are fine but the Cyrillic and Greek ones appear to have encoding problems - e.g. BG has "БЪЛГАРИЯ" and "????????" (`hd` inspection of the download shows these are literally `U+003F` - question marks).

Requesting with a `'Accept: application/rdf+xml;charset=UTF-8'` header makes no difference as it's a statically-hosted file.

The RDF files for individual NUTS codes - e.g. [BG](http://publications.europa.eu/resource/authority/nuts/code/BG) - don't have this problem (so presumably they _do_ have language tags somewhere upstream). We could ask for them to fix it.

We could also crawl all of those pages.

Alternatively we could try to filter the bad labels out as part of the step which [de-dupes multiple labels](https://github.com/GSS-Cogs/GDP-vocabs/blob/master/filters/deDuplicateSkosPrefLabels.sparql). 

Absent a language tag, we need some way to distinguish the good vs bad label.

The order isn't consistent in the file sadly (even if this were to be maintained deterministically by the `sparql` cli tool).

Instead we might be able to do something like `FILTER NOT (regex(str(?label), "\\?"))`.

Indeed we might to have the dedupe step filter instead of concatenating the labels (e.g. taking the first of those without encoding problems).

items.title: cited_by and cites are defined as owl:inverseOf, but in their definition they have the same domain and range.
items.body:
ObjectProperty http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cited_by and http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites are defined as owl:inverseOf

But in their definition they are not inverse, and have the same domain and range.

Thus,
    <!-- http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cited_by -->

    <owl:ObjectProperty rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cited_by">
        <owl:inverseOf rdf:resource="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites"/>
        <rdfs:domain>
            <owl:Class>
                <owl:unionOf rdf:parseType="Collection">
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalExpression"/>
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalResource"/>
                </owl:unionOf>
            </owl:Class>
        </rdfs:domain>
        <rdfs:range rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Thing"/>
        <specificPropertyOf rdf:resource="http://purl.org/dc/terms/relation"/>
        <rdfs:comment xml:lang="en">Inverse of "cites"</rdfs:comment>
        <rdfs:label xml:lang="en">cited by</rdfs:label>
        <owl:versionInfo>created in v1.0</owl:versionInfo>
    </owl:ObjectProperty>
    


    <!-- http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites -->

    <owl:ObjectProperty rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites">
        <rdfs:domain>
            <owl:Class>
                <owl:unionOf rdf:parseType="Collection">
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalExpression"/>
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalResource"/>
                </owl:unionOf>
            </owl:Class>
        </rdfs:domain>
        <rdfs:range rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Thing"/>
        <specificPropertyOf rdf:resource="http://purl.org/dc/terms/relation"/>
        <rdfs:comment xml:lang="en">Citation in the text of the legislation. This may be at the legal resource or legal expression level, as required by the implementation context. This includes verbatim citation and citations in referrals.</rdfs:comment>
        <rdfs:label xml:lang="en">cites</rdfs:label>
        <owl:versionInfo>created in v1.0</owl:versionInfo>
    </owl:ObjectProperty>

Should be:

    <!-- http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cited_by -->

    <owl:ObjectProperty rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cited_by">
        <owl:inverseOf rdf:resource="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites"/>
        <rdfs:range>
            <owl:Class>
                <owl:unionOf rdf:parseType="Collection">
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalExpression"/>
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalResource"/>
                </owl:unionOf>
            </owl:Class>
        </rdfs:range>
        <rdfs:domain rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Thing"/>
        <specificPropertyOf rdf:resource="http://purl.org/dc/terms/relation"/>
        <rdfs:comment xml:lang="en">Inverse of "cites"</rdfs:comment>
        <rdfs:label xml:lang="en">cited by</rdfs:label>
        <owl:versionInfo>created in v1.0</owl:versionInfo>
    </owl:ObjectProperty>
    


    <!-- http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites -->

    <owl:ObjectProperty rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#cites">
        <rdfs:domain>
            <owl:Class>
                <owl:unionOf rdf:parseType="Collection">
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalExpression"/>
                    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://data.europa.eu/eli/ontology#LegalResource"/>
                </owl:unionOf>
            </owl:Class>
        </rdfs:domain>
        <rdfs:range rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Thing"/>
        <specificPropertyOf rdf:resource="http://purl.org/dc/terms/relation"/>
        <rdfs:comment xml:lang="en">Citation in the text of the legislation. This may be at the legal resource or legal expression level, as required by the implementation context. This includes verbatim citation and citations in referrals.</rdfs:comment>
        <rdfs:label xml:lang="en">cites</rdfs:label>
        <owl:versionInfo>created in v1.0</owl:versionInfo>
    </owl:ObjectProperty>

items.title: Proposal for the enhancement of the 'Data theme' controlled vocabulary
items.body:
This proposal is related to the authority table ‘Data theme’ maintained by the EU Publications Office - and has been sent to the appropriate contact point (via email) at the Publications Office.
However, it is also relevant in this context as DCAT-AP recommends that a dcat:Dataset is classified by means of dcat:theme/dct:subject using this controlled vocabulary.

In order to ensure a high quality of data theme annotations, it would be highly beneficial if the controlled vocabulary provided definitions that explained the semantic content of the theme (rather than simply repeating the label). Also, further examples would be of great help too. Naturally, some themes might seem self-explanatory, but still further information would be useful.

This proposed action would help both the authorities publishing datasets, users looking for datasets, and BI specialists.

**Name:** Data theme
**Type:** Concept Scheme (Controlled vocabulary)
**URI:** https://data.europa.eu/euodp/da/data/dataset/data-theme
**Browse content:** https://op.europa.eu/en/web/eu-vocabularies/at-concept-scheme/-/resource/authority/data-theme/?target=Browse&uri=http://publications.europa.eu/resource/authority/data-theme

**Copy of current content:**

Code | Label | Definition
-- | -- | -- | 
AGRI | Agriculture, fisheries, forestry and food | This concept identifies datasets covering     such domains as agriculture, fisheries, forestry or food.
ECON | Economy and finance | This concept identifies datasets covering such domains as economy or finance.
EDUC | Education, culture and sport | This concept identifies datasets covering such domains as education, culture or sport.
ENER | Energy | This concept identifies datasets covering the domain of energy.
ENVI | Environment | This concept identifies datasets covering the domain of environment.
GOVE | Government and public sector | This concept identifies datasets covering     such domains as government or public sector.
HEAL | Health | This concept identifies datasets covering the domain of health.
INTR | International issues | This concept identifies datasets covering  the domain of international issues.
JUST | Justice, legal system and public safety | This concept identifies datasets covering such domains as justice, legal system or public safety.
REGI | Regions and cities | This concept identifies datasets covering such domains as regions or cities.
SOCI | Population and society | This concept identifies datasets covering such domains as population or society.
TECH | Science and technology | This concept identifies datasets covering  such domains as science or technology.
TRAN | Transport | This concept identifies datasets covering the domain of transport.

items.title: Kapitel über bekannte Nutzungen von DCAT-AP.de / DCAT-AP aufnehmen

labels.name: minor
labels.description: This issue can be resolved with the next minor release

labels.name: agreed
labels.description: This issue will be resolved in the next release. See discussion for details

items.body:
Es wird angeregt in der nächsten Version 
a) der Spezifikation oder
b) dynamischer in einem Blog-Beitrag oder als HTML-Seite auf dcat-ap.de 
ein Kapitel aufzunehmen, welches zeigt:
Wer nutzt neben GovData DCAT-AP.de nach?
Welche anderen deutschen Vorhaben erstellen ein eigenes Profil von DCAT-AP?
Welche horizontalen und vertikalen Erweiterung vom EU DCAT-AP gibt es aktuell?

Zweck: 
1. Überblick bekommen über die Nutzer der deutschen, EU und W3C Spezifikation im deutschsprachigen Raum.
2. Möglichkeit geben des Community-Building z.B. um gemeinsam benötigte Vokabulare abzustimmen
3. Verständnis über die Bedeutung von DCAT-AP.de schärfen ausserhalb des GovData Horizontes

Bisher bekannte Nutzer:

**DCAT-AP.de as-is Nutzung**

Bund:
1. GovData - das Datenportal für Deutschland:
 Beispiel DCAT-AP.de Datensatz:  https://www.govdata.de/ckan/dataset/grundschulbezirke.rdf
2. BMFSFJ Open Data Portal:  https://www.daten.bmfsfj.de/
    Beispiel DCAT-AP.de Datensatz: https://www.daten.bmfsfj.de/blob/127546/406af2dd4df95a224ee62538ea2f7c55/uvg-leistungsberechtige-im-quartal-data.rdf
3. BMWi Open Data Portal (coming soon):

**DCAT-AP: eigene vertikale und horizontale Profilierungen analog zu DCAT-AP ** 

Bund

4. Bundesanstalt für Straßenwesen (BASt) mit dem eigenen Profil "DCAT-AP.NAP" 
https://www.its-platform.eu/highlights/harmonised-metadata-national-access-points

Vertikale (Sektorale) Nutzung durch eigene Profile:
EU:
1. BRegDCAT-AP - Spezifikation: Access to Base Register - Spezifikation zur Vernetzung von Basisregistern in Europa - https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/document/2020-05/SC380_D02.01_Final%20Specification%20of%20the%20BRegDCAT-AP_v1.02.docx 
2. GeoDCAT-AP: Spezifikation: https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/geodcat-application-profile-data-portals-europe/distribution/geodcat-ap-101-docx
3. StatDCAT-AP: Spezifikation: https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/statdcat-application-profile-data-portals-europe/distribution/statdcat-ap-v101-pdf

Horizontale (landesspezifische) Nutzung durch Länder:
EU Mitgliedstaaten und EFTA Länder:
8. Italien:https://www.dati.gov.it/sites/default/files/2020-02/linee-guida-cataloghi-dati-profilo-dcat-ap-it-2.pdf 
9. Norwegen: https://data.norge.no/specification/dcat-ap-no/
10. Schweden: https://diggsweden.github.io/DCAT-AP-SE/en/
11. Belgien: http://dcat.be/

items.title: http vs https in CI_Citation or add INSPIRE TGs and Regulations to the Registry

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: This is a discussion about the Validator, any comment is welcome

items.body:
Following this issue https://github.com/inspire-eu-validation/community/issues/319 all URIs from the INSPIRE registry should start with http, even if the registry is redirecting any http requests to https URLs.

However there are also other URIs under the control of INSPIRE for which the validaor will not triger an error if they are starting with https.

Such an URL is used as CI_Citation title for indicating that the network service is conformant with Technical Guidance for the implementation of INSPIRE Download Services (version 3.1):

https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/documents/technical-guidance-implementation-inspire-download-services

First question is, should the validator trigger an error if such URIs would be provided with https instead of http?

Second question is if it should not be better to have all the IRs and TGs as part of the Registry in order to be able to clearly specify to which document the service/dataset/metadata comply.

Same question is if Conformance Classes that are used in the validator should not be also part of the Registry as well?

Iurie

items.title: EU EEAS Sanctions seems to be moved behind a login
items.body: The current url specified in the EU EEAS Sanctions config file, [https://data.europa.eu/euodp/es/data/dataset/consolidated-list-of-persons-groups-and-entities-subject-to-eu-financial-sanctions](https://data.europa.eu/euodp/es/data/dataset/consolidated-list-of-persons-groups-and-entities-subject-to-eu-financial-sanctions), is no longer available, returning a 404. It seems the datasets have been moved behind a login, as per [https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage_en/8442/Consolidated%20list%20of%20sanctions](https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage_en/8442/Consolidated%20list%20of%20sanctions).

items.title: Support field in biblatex entries to overwrite citation formatting
items.body:
Dear all,

I am confronted with issues due to weak intercomperability between special-purpose biblatex packages ([oscola](http://mirrors.ctan.org/macros/latex/contrib/biblatex-contrib/oscola/oscola.pdf) and the CSL oscola. I mentioned this problem previously [here](https://github.com/jgm/pandoc-citeproc/issues/435#issuecomment-647360671) in issue #435 .

I think one solution would be to have pandoc-citeproc look in the biblatex bibliography for a special field like `cite_overwrite = {citation \textit{here}}` and use this one instead of the output from the CSL algorithm. Of course, this would prevent switching easy citation styles, but at least I could use the same bibliography file for biblatex and pandoc-citeproc.

Example of citations that I cannot produce with pandoc-citeproc from biblatex bibliography files:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55188356/85271794-8c893200-b47b-11ea-9953-81d4023bdfba.png)
